docs.text: Welcome to my project website! The purpose of this website is to document my work on personal projects as well as shedding some light on projects I've worked on in the past and my general thinking process behind how I turn my world into code. December 5, 2021
docs.title: Welcome

docs.text: About Greetings! My name is Samuel D. Villegas. I'm a recent Oregon State University Computer Science graduate (Go Beavs!) open to opportunities to work on all sorts of interesting projects. My interests include, but are not limited to: Systems that are scalable and/or incrementally deployable Knowledge systems that leverage data (big and small) to help people make more informed decisions Embedded systems GNU/Linux administration Operating systems Distributed systems Enterprise resource planning (ERP) Business Intelligence / Decision Intelligence Mathematical music composition Programming tools that help other people do their jobs more effectively Project management Domain-specific languages (DSL's) Articulatory phonetics And I also have a goal of one day programming a space robot or some other system out in space. Unfortunately, I don't have the time to pursue every single interest of mine to the depth I'd like to dive to. But, fortunately, that's just another problem to solve! I'm in the process of developing a system that helps organize, prioritize, and schedule my interests for me so I can focus more on the actual projects themselves. I'm not super sure how that'll go—maybe I'll just end up re-inventing the wheel—but I'm excited for where it may take me and what additional insights and perspectives I'll gain along the way. November 15, 2021
docs.title: About

docs.text: Wednesday, September 20, 2023 Worked on variations of the timer project all day. Minor Improvements to the Granola Timer I started with some minor improvements to the granola timer based on what I remember from the time I recorded the process with the initial timer project . This included removing the session summarization textbox (which is not needed for sufficiently well-defined processes), automatically populating the summary field with session information instead, and . Finally Implemented Timer Audio (Yay! Interrupts actually work now!) I also went through some WAV files of different UI sound effects and found some good "focus timer", "relaxation", and "alarm" sounds I could use, and added those to all the different timer projects. Scrum Timer Attempt I created a "Scrum" timer from a copy of the Daily Schedule timer and started trying to outline a Sprint in timer form. I opened up a temporary brainstorming file for helping sketch out my ideas and added a ProductGoal, ProductBacklog, SprintGoal, and SprintBacklog. As I sketched out the basic ideas, adding comments and updating my notes along the way, I started realizing I needed to figure out the more basic task-management logic first before adding these more useful artifacts (backlogs, increments, etc.) to the process. So, I paused development on the Scrum Timer project and created an RTOS Timer, which will focus on the core task-management logic for running tasks, scheduling them, and handling interrupts. RTOS Timer To begin the RTOS timer, I designed a simple "report, context-switch, take a break, work" loop which forms the basis for more real-time operation. The original countdown timer is used as the SysTick interrupt, which periodically reschedules tasks so that no one task can hog the CPU. Next, I added a Dashboard area for displaying session-specific components such as a list of tasks or information about the current task. I added a list of sample tasks and defined their "stack frames" with instructions, an instruction pointer, and stack/heap space for any other memory such as variables and functions used by the instructions. Then, I added some task info components to the Dashboard so we can see information about the current task during the "Running Task" stage, but I had to make the code more readable so that I could more easily fix an issue where the Dashboard wasn't updating properly because I had mixed in some application logic during the prototyping stages of creating the Dashboard components. Turns out, I needed to run only one of those new update functions whenever its data changed instead of updating the entire UI. Finally, I added "Block" and "Yield" buttons (which don't do anything yet) to the Current Instruction section after the "Next Instruction" button and started getting stumped on what I should do next. So, I added a "status" field to the tasks for future use in the scheduling algorithm and spent some time brainstorming ideas for the rest of the RTOS Timer implementation. Other I finally found the board-game money today. I can use it to simulate buying and selling in a simulated market for goods and services. I went outside and picked some green-beans I answered someone's questions about celery-leaf dehydration temperatures and durations I picked a couple of apples from the apple tree in the backyard I went on a walk To Do I still need to finish refactoring the RTOS Timer display code to better handle (in a way that makes more readable sense) the hiding and showing of different elements and adding CSS styling to the Dashboard components. Some Ideas Create a way for signalling to others that you're in a focus-session, and have a pad of paper or audio recorder and an easy-to-follow protocol for the interrupter to make their request Begin templating workspace fields into summary (Q&A, Ideas, Goal, Process, Summary/Feedback/ActualProcess, etc. - look up workspace fields in your Obsidian vaults for the actual fields) After RTOS-Scrum, add in bullet-journal migrations with partial-schedules Adjust session times of Daily Schedule to account for the extra time it takes to write the summary (or not if you decide that the extra time is sufficiently accounted for in the breaks) (We're behind 15 minutes from the actual clock because of having to take additional time to wrap-up summaries) Use a hyphenated 'SUMMARY' field in Daily Schedule templates because there's often multiple tasks completed during a single session September 20, 2023
docs.title: Wednesday, September 20, 2023

docs.title: Finally Implemented Timer Audio (Yay! Interrupts actually work now!)

docs.text: I created a "Scrum" timer from a copy of the Daily Schedule timer and started trying to outline a Sprint in timer form. I opened up a temporary brainstorming file for helping sketch out my ideas and added a ProductGoal, ProductBacklog, SprintGoal, and SprintBacklog. As I sketched out the basic ideas, adding comments and updating my notes along the way, I started realizing I needed to figure out the more basic task-management logic first before adding these more useful artifacts (backlogs, increments, etc.) to the process. So, I paused development on the Scrum Timer project and created an RTOS Timer, which will focus on the core task-management logic for running tasks, scheduling them, and handling interrupts.
docs.title: Scrum Timer Attempt

docs.text: To begin the RTOS timer, I designed a simple "report, context-switch, take a break, work" loop which forms the basis for more real-time operation. The original countdown timer is used as the SysTick interrupt, which periodically reschedules tasks so that no one task can hog the CPU. Next, I added a Dashboard area for displaying session-specific components such as a list of tasks or information about the current task. I added a list of sample tasks and defined their "stack frames" with instructions, an instruction pointer, and stack/heap space for any other memory such as variables and functions used by the instructions. Then, I added some task info components to the Dashboard so we can see information about the current task during the "Running Task" stage, but I had to make the code more readable so that I could more easily fix an issue where the Dashboard wasn't updating properly because I had mixed in some application logic during the prototyping stages of creating the Dashboard components. Turns out, I needed to run only one of those new update functions whenever its data changed instead of updating the entire UI. Finally, I added "Block" and "Yield" buttons (which don't do anything yet) to the Current Instruction section after the "Next Instruction" button and started getting stumped on what I should do next. So, I added a "status" field to the tasks for future use in the scheduling algorithm and spent some time brainstorming ideas for the rest of the RTOS Timer implementation.
docs.title: RTOS Timer

docs.text: I finally found the board-game money today. I can use it to simulate buying and selling in a simulated market for goods and services. I went outside and picked some green-beans I answered someone's questions about celery-leaf dehydration temperatures and durations I picked a couple of apples from the apple tree in the backyard I went on a walk

August 17, 2023 My Development Process This project is an attempt at codifying my development process. It will most likely change over time, and the methods and tools I use now probably won't be the same methods and tools I use later on in my career. I find that explicitly outlining such processes can help ensure that important tasks don't get accidentally skipped or end up getting executed in the wrong order . November 16, 2021

docs.text: My Development Process This project is an attempt at codifying my development process. It will most likely change over time, and the methods and tools I use now probably won't be the same methods and tools I use later on in my career. I find that explicitly outlining such processes can help ensure that important tasks don't get accidentally skipped or end up getting executed in the wrong order . Block Diagram To Do List Kanban Board Project Backlogs (New tasks) Release Backlogs (Sprint-ready tasks) Sprint Backlogs (To Do tasks) In Progress Testing In Review Blocked Suspended Done Gantt Chart Calendar Roadmap Create GitHub repo Feature Request: Make project website editable in Obsidian ... December 5, 2021

docs.text: Process Timer This is a pomodoro-style timer that I use to help organize and track how I use my time. Changelog Designed custom list of setTimeout's to loop through Commented list loop out and re-architect-ed a countdown-timer I had in a way that made it much more intuitive to reason about and attach events and logic to Implemented user experience matched how I wanted the timer to function Roadmap Music I need one sound to play during the sections and another sound to signal when it's time to write the summary. Configuration UI A configuration UI would help usability for others, but I'm the only one using it now, so I'll just hard-code configurations for now. Integrations Still trying to figure out how to connect it with other project ideas such as the "schedules", "plans", "kanban boards", "AIOps", etc. that I have in the works. August 31, 2023
docs.title: Process Timer
